The Againwyrm

Blinksome the afterlight did glaze,
and sniddle reeds went smee;
the hedgerows smelled of almost-days
and tickle-tockled me.

I paused at stones that winked in twain,
at gates of once-before;
my heart went round the roundagain
and tapped a once-a-more.

“Mind loopsome beasts that woo—
where crossroads crease the nowish vale,
the Againwyrm finds you.”

I hefted up a nownot blade,
a keen remember-steel;
and down the turn-and-turning glade
I crept on echo-heel.

The hedges blurred; the hourbells spun;
the sky turned déjà-blue;
twice-started sun unstarted, then
began beginning too.

There round the bend it rounded twice—
the Againwyrm, loop-grim;
with clockscale hide and twizzle eyes
and breath of steeped-machine.

It sissed, “We meet as met we met,”
through dew and rustling yew;
its tail stitched up the wagon-rut
and knotted noon to noon.

I struck the already-place I knew—
the pre-scar on its chin;
the blade went once, went once anew,
went not, then once again.

It folded up its circle-self,
unraveling its hue;
the hedgerows clapped their leafy pelf
for yester-now made new.

I hauled the maybe-muzzled thing
through lanes of when-again;
and Gramfer piped a kettle-hymn:
“Well rung, you cleft the skein!”

Blinksome the afterlight yet glazed,
and sniddle reeds went smee;
the hedgerows hummed of almost-ways—
had we not been? Had we?

The Wantway

’Twas breezly on the meadow-marge,
The bramblewhicks did sway;
The mown-lawn dozed in checker-charge,
And signs said, Keep the Way.

“Beware the Shortcut-Snick, my sprout,
The planners’ prim array;
Trust only grids and granite routes,
And keep to lawful way.”

He buckled up his brambleshoes,
His scuff-stick swung for play;
He pocketed a crumbly map
And sniffed the skimmer-day.

He paused where stone-made footpaths bent
Through bureaucrust and clay;
A hush said, Make a softer curve—
Desire-path wants a way.

He scuffled through the velvet-sward
With shuff and squidge and splay;
A faintling stripe, a slinkweft seam,
Unraveled green to gray.

The Pavewights hissed, “Not there, not there!”
Clipboards in brackish gray;
He doffed his hat and hummed, “Now then—
It’s wishcut time today.”

Then joggers, dogs, and dapperbees
Came zig and zag to play;
Their footfalls, plock by plocket-plock,
Beat out the wantway’s way.

Yet mind the moss and beetlefolk—
Step light where shadows lay;
Desire is best when gentle-soled,”
The dappled breezes say.

The grass ungreened to honest earth,
A tawny thread of yay;
A throughline, simple, true as thirst—
A path that chose to stay.

Back home he came, galumph and grin,
Across the wantway’s lay;
“O flumptious day! Caloo! Calay!”
They jigged a jig-of-May.

The Boardrumph

The Clavichortle Room

Shun clangly crash-a-phones;

The standerlings stood, not toppling,

The Mapwyrm

the meridims were pale;
the legend-lamps were softly plumbed,
the towns lay mothlike, frail.

fold-serpent of the plain;
it loops your northle clean apart
and sips your compass-brain.”

packed pocket-lore against the drear,

the coastlines hissed with saltish fire,
the hills wore contour-cap.

through contour-shadowed gloom;
its copper teeth were rivet-clawed,
its breath a papery plume.

the creasewood hushed from rim to rim,

Ballad of Layover Bay

where timetide taps the piers;
The gategulls haggle the foam to gray
and tingle the waiting ears.

and stow your yawns away;

beware the wide delay.

keep snacklets close at hand;
For dallysprays and loiterfins
are common in this strand."

through turnstile drifts of spray;
The snack-bar cliffs gave gingery help
to hearts that would delay.

all carousel-striped and spry;
It flittered round my waiting dish
and winked a tarmac eye.

From under Loudhailer Bluffs it rose—
the Lay’n’Wait Wyrm uncurled;

it fogged the posting world.

all perforate and keen;

that clutch the in-between.

the timetable beast did reel;
I poked its snoot, its stickers sagged—
it bonked a final peal.

Back past the snackulous dunes I ran,
where Ticketock Tip held sway;
He flapped his cap, a peppered fan,
"The lag is kept at bay!"

O claptious noon! Huzzah, hooray!
Let gategulls wheel and bray;
We drum the docks and shout our say—
bright luck to Layover Bay!

poem:
The Glimmerwheels of Monte Carlo

Glimmerbright the seaside night; the yachts hummed low with gloam,
and gilted domes went shimmer-shine above the sugared foam;
the chip-chime chirred, the rouleway purred, a whirry-whisking show—
oh Montecarlequinning lights, that bid the bold to go!

“Mind you,” croaked an auntied sage, “beware the spinnywog!
The house-edge has a nibble-bite that gnaws the braggart’s log.
Keep budget-buckles cinchy-tight; let whimsies not be guide;
and pack a plan, you lucklet—let patience be your stride.”

I primed my purse with portioned chips, in stacks of tidy snow,
I knotted will to wary wits and let the rashness go;
I ran a million jitter-jigs, in simulatronic breeze,
to sound the chanceful chaparral and seed the random seas.

Through baccarat and blinkle-slots I wended, soft and slow,
past dice that clacked like pebble-rain in crapsalicious flow;
the Rouléwock went whirr-purr-whirr, its grin a lacquered bowl,
and dealers dealt with silken hands, each eyebrow cool and droll.

I hedged my hedgy hedgerows, placed a pebble on the red,
then drifted light to black again, where riskling rumor led;
I martied not, nor tilt-tripped wild; I let the bellies roll,
and skimmed the skimmy edges of the whirligigging soul.

And when the glimmerwheel drew breath, a hushling breezed the room;
my number sprit-sprang sunrise-hot—fizzmirth and little boom;
a sprig of wins—not dragon-large, but jolly small and neat—
I scooped the sprangle-gleaming chips and danced away on feet.

Home down the Miramarry steps I skippled, grin aglow,
past tuxied sprites and moon-sweet sails that noddled to and fro;
“O fabjulune!” my auntie sang, “Hooraloo! Hooralay!
Did prudence guard your glimmer-purse and hubris keep at bay?”

I bowed and chimed, “Enough to toast the sea with bubbles bright;
and after that, to wander off before the biting night.
For Monte Carlo twinkleswitches hearts to folly’s brink—
but wiser whirls the wanderer who knows just when to wink.”

So glimmerbright the seaside stays; the yachts hum low with gloam;
beware the merry spinnywog and budget-button home;
take plan and poise; when fortune nods, don’t tarry till you rue—
then croon your luck and skippyskip, while waves go woo-woo-woo.

The Brunebutter Ballad

poem:
Creep-thrum and the Nittlecreep

Blinver dusk was grivver-cold; the hedgerows hushlings stooped,
While snudgy moss in drumble folds along the flagstones looped;
The lampmoths sang in filament, all glimmer-green and deep—
And every gap and cobble-step went creep and creep and creep.

“Mind well the Nittlecreep, my sprout—the slow-toothed, velvet creep!
Its slipshade grin, its syrup-spin, its nuzzle-soft and steep.
Beware the ooze that smiles at you; beware the snaileye stare—
The creep that never leaps at all, but finds you unaware.”

I took my bramblestaff in hand, my kettle-lid for shield,
A jitterlight within my pack, best banishers I wield;
I muttered runes of shuffle-quick, of spurtle-step and sweep,
And ventured down the garden stones to parley with the creep.

It slouched from under stair and sill, a quilt of dusk and dew,
With swaying fringe of nettle-fur and button-eyes of blue;
Its feelstreels tapped the paving squares, its whisperwhiskers peep—
O murkling mild and many-miles: the Nittlecreep, the creep!

We bargained by the pump and pail; it hummed a honeyed drone,
It braided weeks around my boots and cinched them to the stone;
I stamped a stamp, I swirled my broom, I flickerflung a spark—
But creep is patient as a clock and sips the edges dark.

So I unspooled a scarlet thread and pegged the margins tight,
I chalked a ring of wakeful words and set my jitterlight;
The creature blinked, then slumped and slid, like pudding from a heap,
It slubbed away with slippered sway—the Nittlecreep, the creep.

Now keep your thresholds nimble-swept, your corners clear and bright,
Let nonsense songs be lantern-strong against the nibble night;
For not with fang nor rattleglaive, but with a steady keep,
We hearten halls and hedge the crawl of every hushborn creep.

that sneaky beak can slip and maul!

and wax the twine before the awl.

so nizzle-neat, no fray at all;

led twirly-twine behind the awl.

the prickle-peck near pronged his paw!

all born beneath the Borebright Awl.

The Clatterphase

went wimple-wamble down the dale;
through crumple-foam and whisper-caves

that cross-tongued hum, the cancel-bite;
the beat-behemoth snoops about—

take up thy tuning-fork and helm;
wear nodal boots and counter-chains,
lest scumble-surge o'erwhelm the realm."

a nodal net that neatly fit—
a brave though bimble-bumptious fella.

my counter-chanson learned by heart,

came snorfling up the ripple-glade
to scrump the calm and scrobble day.

the hush said "whum!" and then said "more!"

beats beat their beats to even thread;
its buzz unbuzzed from nose to toes—
the Clatterphase went fizzle-dead.

its cancel-bite could bite no more.

and tiptoed off the jitter-floor.

go wimple-wamble kind and clear;

a silken sheet from here to here.

When murkish mizzle mumbled eaves, and gutters gabble-glowed,

The flaggy lanes went splosh-a-spell; the chimneys coughed with spray,
And toadstool clocks went drip-drip-drip along the dampish day.

“Mind, sprigling, mind the Drizzlegnash, that gnaws the netted rain!
Its squelch-toothed grin will tear a brim and rattle rib and cane.
Shun Slorptails that go flitter-flud, and Squinny-gnats that flay—
But take the Paraplum,” he said, “and broll your fears away.”

I grasped the Paraplum by crook; its spine was sprung with gleam,
A ribbing star of shadowstuff, sewn tight with sunlit seam;
I snapped it wide—kerflap! kerflue!—a night within the day,
And puffing winds went huff-a-hum beneath its dark array.

Down puddle-path I sloshed along through ferny gurgle-glooms,
Past snickles of the weather-witch and moggling mushroom rooms,
When, sodden-lurking, out it slunk—the fanged Drizzlegnash,
Its dripjaw clacked, its noodle-neck went swoggle-swish and lash!

It sniffed the shade; it bit the brim; it gnurled a gusty bleat—
I twirled the Paraplum about; the splatters missed my feet;
With plash and clash and scuddleshank we wheeled in slither-spree,
Till snap! I snared its squishy snout and brollicuffed it free.

The gales un-gulped; the cloud-herds broke; the drizzle lost its gree;
The Drizzlegnash went gurgle-gone, a soppy skulking flea.
I folded up my Paraplum—click-click the spokes all sang—
And scuddled home through puddletowns where bellied raindrops hang.

“Have you un-gnashed the Drizzlegnash?” the old one blunk and beamed.
I whooped a brimming brolla-hey; the eaves with gladness gleamed.
He hung the Paraplum by door; the drops played tinky-tong,
And kettle-steams and hearthish light went snug as woolly song.

Now murkish mizzles mumble less, though gutters gabble still;
Where Paraplum once bloomed its night, the panes are starry-chill.
When fluthered skies go squall-a-swoop and puddle-goblins play,
We lift our brave dear Paraplum and turn the rain away.

The Sciencifair

Did whorl and wimble round the stand;
All mizzly hummed the circuit-lamps,
And charts lay close at hand.

"Beware the Fizzfume, child o' mine!
The Sparkwyrm's sizzler-glare!
Strap tight thy goggles, toe the line—
Prepare, prepare, prepare!

Keep hair-ties, labcoat buttoned snug,
Label axes true and square;
Bring tongs and towel, plug by plug,
Control thy variables fair.

He donned the frothproof glove and coat,
Primed pipette, timer, blade;
He set his graph and ballast-note,
Calibrations made.

And while in thunkish muse he stood,
The bell went brang and bong;
The Bunsenkins breathed blue and good,
The judge-birds came along.

Clicker-clack! went meter-gnomes,
Zizz-zazz the laser's beam;
The Datasprite unfurled its tomes—
A test, a trial, a scheme.

Out popped a Glorp of dropple-goo,
It splashed a splattle flare;
He dabbed it up with towel-true
And logged the error fair.

He snared the rogue confounder-beast
With control-cords neat and tight;
He fit the curve from west to east,
Till numbers sang outright.

O marvel-bright! Huzzoodle-day!
They pinned a ribbobright!
He skipple-stepped the jolly way,
Home, experigumphing light.

"And didst thou tame the Fizzfume grim,
And cool the Sparkwyrm's glare?
Come, tell it all from brim to brim,
Thy Sciencifairing flair!"

He waved his board of charts and notes,
Ribbobright on his vest;
"I kept my cool and all my quotes—
My method passed the test!"

'Twas beaker-bright; the fribble clamps
Lay still beside the stand;
All mellow-soft the circuit-lamps—
Hurraly through the land!

Ballad of the Jammerjam

the whirrle-wheels did wake;
the shiver-sheets in shuffle-fand
went sniggle, snag, and shake.

guard all your bravish thumbs!

those rubber-rumple drums!

bring tweezers, calm, and light;
consult the sacred Troubleswork—
the foldy scroll of might."

he cracked the tray with click and clack—
the creakling paper-farm.

a jamster, jam and grim;
it gridged its gears with scratchy maw
and rasped a papery hymn.

and wiggled, wagged, and wonk;
he soothed the sensors' blinkish blight,
defluffed the fuzz and gunk.

poem:
Ballad of the Umbrellikin

Splish-splush, the drabbish drops went dreep
through gully-gleam and lane;
the gusty gullups rumble-creep,
and spouts went glub with rain.

Tight-hold your bumbershade, my sprout—
the Mizzlegrum’s abroad;
his gloopy grin slurps lanterns out,
his splash-step slaps the sod.

He took his umbrellikin of noir,
with whalebone ribs a-gleam;
a spring-spun shushery he wore,
a roof against the stream.

By puddle-stack and spouty stair,
past dripstone, sump, and seam,
he stalked the mizzlemurkish air
that clouded into dream.

Out swoggled from a drain-mouth lair
the Mizzlegrum up loomed—
a slathery snout, a tangle-hair,
a squall inside its plume.

He twirled the stem; the canvas bloomed—
a nightflower, round and wide;
flitter-flap! the dripworld swooned,
the splash-beast slid aside.

With swizzle-swerve and shieldy flare
he fenced the bluster-mite;
the Mizzlegrum, wind-worried there,
went slumping into night.

Home splosh he came through glimmered streets,
his 'brell a hushwing dome;
huzzuggle rose from chimney-heats—
how splendiflush, to home!

Now mildwise lie the dripful dews,
the bumbershade unbends;
while nuzzlewinds go purling through,
and pitter-mutter ends.

poem:
Monte Carlowhim

’Twas rundle-night in Monte Carlo; spinwheels purred and glow,
The chiplets clacked in clinkly stacks, the champagne fizzed just so;
The gausslings drifted through the lights, the tossers toss-and-throw,
And luckaloons in velvet loons went flittering to and fro.

“Beware the Martingrins, my child, the Ruin-snap that bites!
Shun sleek martingales that grin; they hide the ruin blights!
Take up thy Markov chain-mail coat and Cheby-shield for fights,
And pack a seed, ten-thou of runs, and bins in tidy flights.”

I set my sigma-sabre drawn, my bounds both high and low;
A confinet of ninety-five, a delta-sigil’s glow;
I stowed my randershank device to stir the underflow,
And keened my varimathic ear for whispish riskle-snow.

Through clatterpits of dice and decks, through spinny-whirr I strode,
Past croupier crabs with clicking claws who kept the chanceman’s code;
I hummed stochanto lullabies along the velvet road,
Until the Gaudy Gradient rose— a flicker-beast that flowed.

And as in deep expectimath I leaned by lamplight’s brim,
The Fat-Tail Wyrm of Monte risk came lolloping and grim;
Its bell-curve back was jaggery; its kurt was lept and prim,
Its ruin-jaws went snap-snap-snack with variclaw and vim.

I swung my sigma-sabre then—four sigmas, maybe more—
My Markov chain-mail chimed a ring; my Cheby-shield held sure;
We fenced with swash of sample paths across the roulette floor,
Till bootstraps whipped and p-values yipped— I cleft its tail’s long roar.

I bound its fangs with bounds of Hoeff; with Bennett’s cord I tied,
I tamed its spikes with smoothing spikes; its scary skew I plied;
I logged my draws and histo-bars; the means behaved and sighed,
And Monte’s walls went hush-a-breathe; the dealers gently cried.

I took its riskle-tongue as proof and hurried home apace—
Back through the lamp-lit chipling lanes to that familiar face;
My elder sat by spreadsheets bright, a grin upon his place,
And thresh of cards made cozy winds around our little space.

“O lucksome noon, you golden boon!” He clapped his hands and sang:
“Huzzaroo! Your plan held true— you ran the randerslang!
Come prance the halls, brave simulant; let bell and goblet clang—
For tales and tails are tamed today, and variance lost its fang!”

poem:
The Gridlewyrm of the Folded Map

In foldlight hour the parchment seas
Went skindle-splied with greases;
Meridlings hummed through longilines,
And legends loosed their leases.

Glyphleaves shook in mapwood glens,
The scale-bars clicked like beetles;
The compass rose unpetaled winds—
A sneeze of northly needles.

Mind the Gridlewyrm, my sprout—
That gnaws the blanky margins;
It gulps the edges inside out
And burps up bristly pargings.

Steer wide the Tatterfold, as well,
Where tearwinds snatch your tracing;
The Nullanights with inkless bell
Go hushly, town-erasing.

He took his chart-knife, flex and keen,
His quadrant-spear of pewter;
He packed a crumb of lantern-green,
A rustly route-computer.

Through patterplots of roads he slid,
Past hillwhorl, brook, and border;
He heard a gridle-growly rid—
A crosshatch out of order.

Up curled the Gridlewyrm, all scales
Of scale-bars, ticked and tallyed;
Its tongue went eastle, westle flails,
Its breath made contours valleyed.

He flipped the map to foldle-four,
Then foldle-five and sixes;
He sprung a crease like thunder-door
And pinched it in the fixies.

It wriggled, wrung, and ravel-snapped,
A crumple, then a dotling;
He snipped its knot with chart-knife clapped,
And stamped the curl to nothling.

Back through the windlewest he came,
All inkthrum bright and whistly.
“O scrawlbright day! Hah-lulla-name!”
He laughed, map-cheeked and mistly.

The foldlight hour grew smooth and mild;
The meridlings went sleepy;
Longilines rocked a drowsen child,
And legends curled up, keepy.

The Ballad of the Glimble-Cam

went whurling through the vale,

keep cap till time is ripe;

and chased the shy balloon.

Ballad of the Déjà-Whim

And knot your Now with knotlings true.

A bladeling forged of tick and tock;

By Yesterpool and After-Rock.

The Interfrix

Sprindle-hour, the slivery reeds
went twindle-wind along the weir;
crosshatching waves in cancelweaves,
and hushquake packed the air.

Take heed the Interfrix, small sprout—
that janglebeast of bands!
Shun Nullgnats burbling in and out,
and Crosstitch Cranes with wands;
for they tug tones to tangle-tune,
unlace the lumen-threads,
till noon and midnight croon as one
and twins trip twissled treads.

He hefted up his nodal-rod,
the clacksome counter-gleam;
struck true his helm of Unishod,
and trod the rimpled stream.

He crouched beside a buckled stump
and counted breaths to ten;
the air went skell, the ripples clumped—
then skirled apart again.

Through scrambelines and echo-burr
there rose a rimpled mane:
the Interfrix, with jangle-fur
and eyes set out-of-plane.

Knick-knack the nodal-rod he swung,
a lash of antiphase;
the beastlet babbled crosswise tongue
and flung its cancel-blaze.
He stepped a notch to counter-jut,
to find the proper node;
his rod went clip-snap through its knot—
the static thing implode.

The noise unknotted in a blink,
the hushquake loosed its seam;
the Interfrix went down a-splink
to fizzled threads of dream.

Back clop he came by muffled lanes,
his nodal-rod still bright;
“O ho!” they cried by windowpanes,
“the waves run fair tonight!”
He caper-cut the cancelgreen
and whooped, “Huzzaloo!”
The clocks uncrossed; the day grew clean;
the reeds ran single, true.

Sprindle-hour, the slivery reeds
no twindle-tangle bear;
the wavetwine smooths to simple weaves,
and quiet combs the air.

poem:
The Ballad of the Slinking Creep

When twilglow brushed the twizzle-weeds
And murmling mists went deep,
The glimble-lanes made hushy deeds,
And out there, something—Creep.

“Mind not the nuzzled night,” said Gran,
“Yet heed its slink-o-peep;
It skritches through the pottle-pan—
Beware the Slinking Creep!

“It sips the squeaks from cricket songs,
It nibbles corners neat;
It streels your spine in slubbered tongs,
It loves a lonesome street.

“So pack your pluck, my pebble-heart;
Take bramblecoat and cap;
Prime up your sparkled thrumble-dart,
And map the moonward map.”

I buckled boots of bristlehide,
My grimmer-glass I keep;
A whirlig blade at belt I tied
To snip the snithered sleep.

Through snurfle-fog and grumble-bough,
Where drimble shadows leap,
I listened with a furrowed brow
For whisper-woven Creep.

It squoggled from the gutter seam,
A blur, a blottle sweep—
With tatter-breath and candle-gleam,
Came sideling, sideling Creep.

Its slippers made a sussur-press,
Its eyes were lantern-deep;
It folded night in crinkled dress
And knitted hush to keep.

I flicked my whittle-whirl to sing,
A brightling, brizzle sweep;
It chimed a chim of steely ring
Across the gnashsome Creep.

We flailed through nettle, nook, and gorse—
A skirl, a skrangle peep—
Till clatter-clave with glimber force
Undid the nubbled Creep.

I scooped its gloom in ginger sack,
A pinch of sooted sleep,
And pinned it with a thistle-tack
To still its slithered creep.

Then homeward down the hobstone mile,
Past drowsy cows that cheep,
I trudged with dusk inside a vial,
Well-tamed and tiny Creep.

“O jubil-spin!” cried kin and kin,
“Huzzah! Come sup and heap!
You brought the bravest bramble-win—
You bottled up the Creep!”

We danced the hearth to tickle-time,
With custard-clouds to steep,
And sang a zindle-jingled rhyme
Till none of us could creep.

The Ballad of Layover Bay

And foglets trilled awry.

The clocks that cling and crunch!

And queues that thrum and bunch!

And kiosks chirped “Board now!”
The baggagewyrms in beltish hugs
Went clatter-swish-kachow.

Its scales were ticking—clink-a-chink!—
It clouded half the world.

He whistled breezy-bright;

Till time said “Let me be.”

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Thrumble-Path

In gloamsome hour the nettles nuzzed,
hedgebirds hummed askew;
The meadow’s nap lay rimple-fuzzed
where wanderfeet went through.

“Mind, moppet,” croaked the Pavebind-post,
with painty finger wag,
“Step where the bricklines brag the most,
and not the meadow’s shag.”

Yet skitterkeen my soles took heart,
by mapless wish and math,
and pressed a silver start-of-start—
the firstling desire-path.

Up from the sward, with bylawoofs,
the Turfgnash Grumple sprang;
its buckleplates and badgey hooves
went clinkle-clankle-clang.

“Unstep!” it blethered, “Keep the grid!
Uncrumple back your roam!”
I set my treadstaff firm and slid
between the cloverfoam.

We wheeled in whuffle, hush and hiss,
through stitchworn, seedling seam;
each pass I made, a leanling kiss
pressed pale the grass’s green.

The Grumple gnashed its gravelmouth,
but found no grip to stay;
my longsteps poured their south-by-south—
the wishway slicked to clay.

Thread upon thread the meadow-lace
unlooped beneath my heel;
a hushroad grew in tressy grace,
a soft and certain keel.

Back by the posts, the paint went dumb,
the hedgebirds trilled me through;
“O glimful stride! Hurraye! Hum-hum!”
sang puddles, leaf, and yew.

And still at dusk the nettles nuzz,
and dusk-breeze combs the swath;
the world remakes its lawful buzz
around the thrumble-path.

The Fizzle-Fair of Science

all bristle, tape, and glue;

went thrumble through the queue.

clamp tight the clatter-stand;
Beware the Fizzle-pop that kicks,
the Splashenblaze that fanned."

and primed the soda cone;
He checked the graph for squiggle-fault,
then turned the switcher on.

The Teslapuff went zizzle-zoom,
the lemon lantern glowed;
A dronelet looped the rafters' gloom,
a slime-jar sproinged and flowed.

Then through the murmur-mass there came
two badge-bedazzled eyes;

they hummed their "tell us, why's."

unclipped the burble-hose;

how pressure builds and goes.

a sparkling, fizzy fount;

to nearly scout the mount.

then beamed a beamful grin;
"Your method neat, your measures rich—
now pack this ribbon in."

He scootle-skipped the gym-floor tiles,
his folks came wobble-cheer;
"O sparkle-bright, you clever whiles!"

through dusk's soft tinker-glow;

poem:
The Foggenwight at Drumble-Dawn

At drumble-dawn the mizzlefog
went swither-slow along the lane;
it snorled the hedge and muffled bog
and quilted dew on paling-pane.

It fluthered round the milk-stone trough,
a hushling, plushling, silken skein;
it smudged the path and soothed the cough
of chimneys in their ghostly grain.

They whisper of the Foggenwight
who gathers cold from nettle-gnash;
its lampish eyes are morning-light,
its whiskers drip with dewish splash.

I saw it through the lolling haze,
a bumblesleek and gentle thing;
it wove the dawn in mufflemays
and wore the bell of thrush’s ring.

It nuzzled up the slumbered street
and sippled sun from window-sills;
it tidied webs with tender feet
and shivered off the hillward chills.

Then, slip by slip, the swaddlemist
unravelled into daybright spray;
the Foggenwight blew one cold kiss
and purl-turned back to nither-grey.

And drumble-dawn went brindle-bright,
the hedges shook their wetting mane;
but somewhere in the thinning light
the Foggenwight hummed soft again.

The Conferoom Caper

Went blip and bleep and brine,
While flipchart fronds, with marker-hand,
Made squiggles down the spine.

“Thy notes and nibbled brain!
Beware the Grumblegenda’s sea,

poem:
The Voltivark and the Third-Rail Hum

In tramblehours the tunnels groan;
the switchlings jink in shadowfume;
All sparklish lie the iron bones,
while third-rail murmurs hummelume.

“Bewarn the Voltivark, dear kin;
its crackle-maw, its flickerfang!
Beware the Tizzleserpent thin,
and shun the shoe-rail’s sizzle-sang!”

He clutched his insul-saber tight,
and donned a gaunt of vulcanproof;
He trod the ballast-blackling night
beneath the sleepers’ sootish roof.

He paused by stutter-sign and stone,
and heard the third-rail hum go on,
a long ohm-ode of copper tone—
a graveldrum of under-song.

And lo! the Voltivark, aglow,
came skirl-skittering, arc-toed, trim;
Its whisker-coils were fizzlenow,
its eyes twin lamps in cablegloom.

Zip-zap it cracked its bristle-arc;
the tieplates rang with whirr and drum;
He swung; the sparks made starry marks
that answered back the thunderhum.

Skritch-crack! with clamp and cunning care,
he bridled it with insul-rope;
He bent its zindle ohmward fair,
and lulled its hiss to hummer-hope.

He led it, humming, soft and low,
through girder-vale and tunnel-vine;
“O gladsome gauge!” the staithmen crowed,
“The Voltivark is on the line!”

“Come rest,” he said, “no scald nor bite—
just purr within the sleeper’s loam.”
It kept a steadfast metrolight
and held the third-rail hum at home.

In tramblehours the tunnels croon;
the switchlings jink in shadowfume;
All lampish lie the iron bones,
and third-rail keeps its hummelume.

prompt: Write a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Burn‑inwock

At gloam‑o’‑clock the clicky keys were drumming soft and thin,
The cursors fizzled zigzag‑bright and stitched a glow‑grin in;
The widget‑wights went shimble‑sham through tabs of teal and tin,
While ghostlets grinned with fainty‑stain—the foretaste of burn‑in.

Heed, sprout, the Burn‑inwock: its ghosty jaws will grin;
Those bander‑bars and clingy glyphs that never quite give in.
Steer clear the Stucksy Pixel‑sprite, the Icon‑Grimp and kin,
And keep thy saver whirr‑a‑whirr, lest images burn in.

He hefted up his Ditherblade; for many ticks had been
The priming of the Saverclock and Shuffle‑shifting within;
He dimmed the glare to moonish‑ware, slid Nightshade Filter in,
Then hummed a lull to pixels all, to ward the wick of burn‑in.

He idled near the status trees and clicked a mousy rune,
When up from under toolbar fog there burbled bleep and din;
A stripèd thing with scorchy breath, a stare like noon‑at‑noon,
Came flarbling through the widget‑wild—the dreaded Burn‑inwocklin!

Its logo‑slats were welded wide, its afterglimmers thin,
It trailed a sash of menu‑bars all stampèd into skin;
It hissed in phosphor‑thistle tones, “I win, I stay, I pin,”
And smeared its grin across the grid—oh, sticky, slow burn‑in!

Flip‑flap! the Ditherblade went whisk; the jitter‑jutter spin,
The Saverclock kept shuffle‑steps; the pixels pranced within;
He swipe‑and‑shifted, pano‑drifted, cycled dark to dim,
Till bander‑bars fell flitter‑bits and vanished back within.

It gave a sputter‑sizzle sigh, a plastiglassy thin,
Then blinked to blank; the pane went pure, as river after rain;
He wrapped the screen in saver‑sheen and let night‑rest begin,
And back he went through sidebar lanes, with quiet, ghostless brain.

“And hast thou quelled the Burn‑inwock? Come, set the kettle in!
We’ll toast with cocoa‑amber foam the pixels fresh and clean;
Oh, gladsome day! hura‑hurree! No shadow‑glyphs remain—
Come dance the Scrollo‑reel with me, beneath a ghostless sheen.”

So mind the glow and pace thy gaze; let shufflemodes begin,
Let breaks and blanks and bedtime drift be daily woven in;
For thus we foil the ghosty glaze and keep our windows grin—
A merry screen, a merry eye, and none of that burn‑in.

poem:
The Hollerquin of the Underpass

It was underglow; the clangles clung,
And rivet-throats went ring-a-rung;
Graffiglare on pillar-skin,
While driplets droned a murmur-hymn.

Beneath the overroad’s iron ribs
The tramblewind did flisk the dribs;
And tire-whales in the far-off stream
Went rumble-boom with oily gleam.

Out crept the Hollerquin, thin as fog,
With loop-back lungs and echo-log;
It doppel-sang what mouths had thrown,
And fed on foundlings of their tone.

I called, “Who walks this baffle-bed?”
It called me back with tinsel dread:
“Who walks this baffle-bed? Who, who?”
And shivered steel with afterblue.

A skateboard spark went skitter-splay,
A pigeon loosed its coo-cascade;
The dripclocks ticked in rusty gray,
And girders hummed like colonnade.

A bench-eld man in blanketcoat
Spoke low through steam of paper-boat:
“Mind not the Hollerquin,” said he,
“It only eats what words you free.”

But still it sleeked along the soot,
A mirror-thing with mocker-foot;
It chitterbacked my hum and cough,
It ping-returned my leaving scoff.

I raised my braver-lantern tin,
All dent and dusk and handlepin;
I swung till shadow-wool unspooled,
And clankle-light the arches pooled.

The Hollerquin went boom-aloof,
Rewove itself in rib and roof;
It mouthed my light in lesser bloom,
A hush-of-hush, an echoloom.

So down the trumbleroad I trod,
Past puddle-iris, grime and sod;
Behind me rolled the underpass,
And every step returned, alas.

It croons where clangles cling and ring,
The Hollerquin, the mirror-thing;
In underglow, where voices pass,
It keeps their shiverings in glass.

The Jamber-Clack

At clockety noon the traylings stacked,
The printbox hummed in burble-tone;
All paprish leaves lay crisp and packed,
While status lights blinked green-alone.

Then sneaking through the feeders black,
A Jamber-Clack did snag and gnaw;
It crinkle-crunched the rimpled stack,
And ground a grumple in its jaw.

Mind this, young typeling: square the ream,
Fan softly; dust the sprockle-lips;
Shun crinkle-nicks and dog-eared seam,
Keep lint away from roller-grips.

I gripped my de-jam wand and grinned,
I popped the hatch—click-snap the seam;
I toggled trays, unplugged the wind,
And peered into its paper-dream.

Kricks and clacks, the crankle gears,
The rollers hissed in rubber wrath;
I coaxed the snag despite its jeers,
And threaded leaves along their path.

I yankled free the crumple-knot,

Its grip unsnarled, its gripe forgot,
And smooth the pages kissed the wheel.

Back to the desks I briskly came—
“All clear?” they peered with hopeful eye;
I waved the freed, unruffled ream—
“O gladsome go! Now let it fly!”

Oh zingy noon! Hooray-hooray!
The desklings danced in clicky rows;
The print-chimes chimmed a clack-a-day,
And streamy sheets like snowstreams flowed.

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Againwyrm

Gleamgloom slid on thrumble hush; the twindle-branches bowed,
And whorlyweeds in wobble pits went burbling, loop-aloud;
All dapplemotes went ring-a-ree through hollow-vales of blue—
It seemed it had already seemed: the smell of déjà-dew.

“Mind thee the Againwyrm, child,” old Gransire murped and frowned;
“Its spiral stare eats yester-air and chews the nowness round.
It coils the path you mean to take with backwhirl, round-and-when;
It nibbles at your going forth and hands it back again.”

I fetched my yestersteelful blade, a twicesharp refrain,
And donned the helm of Remever, stitched with threads of Then;
I gripped a counterclockward haft of neveridle wood,
And paced the Perhapstree’s shadowbank where If and Maybe stood.

I waited through the tickletocks, the hush-a-when, the while,
Till dupplight folded overleaf in twice-remembered style;
A footfall fell, fell once-again, then fell where it had been—
And from the loopershade it slid: the Againwyrm, lean and green.

Its eyes were little spiraclaws that curled the future thin,
Its tongue went “Once! Again!” again, and wound where once had been;
Its scales were slick with everyet, its breath a circlune gust,
It wagged a tail of roundelay and lapped the path to dust.

No sooner had it hissed anew, I raised my echo-blade;
I swung a crosswise figure-eight, a cleaving promenade—
Snickersnap? Nay, rindlecrack! through coils of second-same,
I split the knot of nowness twice and out unlooped its name.

Down fell the twine of yesterday; the ground forgot to spin.
The Perhapstree stood perhapless; air turned crisp and thin.
I borne the felled Againwyrm’s head, still mouthing “Yet again,”
And strode to Gransire’s hearth of Once, now freshened into When.

“O loop-sprung joy!” he cry-whooped then, “O thrice-unwinding boon!
You’ve cut the knot the hours tied and chased away the rune.
Come sip the tea of Only-Now, let roundabout be through—”
And still I swear I heard the dusk say, “Have we done this too?”

Gleamgloom rose in thrumble hush; the twindle-branches bowed,
And whorlyweeds in wobble pits went burbling, soft and proud;
All dapplemotes went ring-a-roe through hollow-vales anew—
It seemed it had not seemed before—yet smelled of déjà-dew.

The Riffraffoon in the Music Room

The floorboards hummed in tune;

The bellowbox went whumm;
The violings trilled whirligales,
The timpans thrumpty-thrum.

And dodge the Riffraffoon!”

My bow of oakmaroon;
I tuned the catgut clink-and-splash
By silver metragoon.

Past sheets of noteful snow;

Where hushes come and go.

Then ho! from out the velvet case
A grumble burst in tune;
It loop-the-looped around the space—
The sly Riffraffoon!

It chitterjazzed a scattery splash,
A branglebang buffoon;
I countered with a snickle-smash—
A keen arpeggioon.

We wrangle-waltzed in clatter-flash
Around the stool and bassoon;
I flung a bold pizzaka-splash
And snared the Riffraffoon.

Back through the scorey corridor
I skip-step-sailed by noon;
My case aglow with hush and roar,
Tamed tight: the Riffraffoon.

The Maestro whooped; the benches boomed,
Confetti notes festoon;
We whirled a reel till candles bloomed—
Huzzah! triumphant tune!

poem:
The Lingerlark of Layover Bay

At slack-of-sail the tide went squine,
and fog came seep-and-sueting;
the pilings knurred with brine-on-brine,
the buoys went tutel-tuting.

Those layfolk pooled at Layover Bay,
all ticket-damp and drowdy,
sipped steamertea to keep delay
from growing brineward-rowdy.

“Mind well the Lingerlark,” said Gran,
“that haunts the quay-side nettles;
it pecks the minutes out of span
and rusts the harbor kettles.

“With lantern-beak and latch-hook wing,
it snares the faint of going;
it sips your sigh, a patient thing,
and keeps the timetide slowing.”

I gripped my whistleblade of steel,
my pocket-clock kept humming;
I paced the planks with salt for heel
to set the leaving coming.

And while the customs-lanterns dinned
and moor-chains thrung and quivered,
down slid from out the holdless wind
the Lingerlark, long-livered.

Its eyes were waiting-rooms of gray,
its plumes like baggage stickers;
it rasped the clocks of Layover Bay
with many lazy flickers.

“Now sing!” my whistleblade cried bright,
and sprang in chirr and thunder;
I split its hush from left to right
and loosed the tide asunder.

It flounced and fell between the piers,
its nettle-wings unweaving;
the minutes rinsed of drag-born fears,
and boats grew keen for leaving.

The bunting woke; the harbor sang; we drummed the rails in praising;
the timetables unclenched at last—the outward bells were blazing.

No longer slack, the tide unspooled,
and stroked the hulls toward traveling;
the fog unlaced its suety rule,
and all the buoys quit babbling.

The Awl and the Thrumblegrin

went whorl-and-whittle round the bench;
The pucker-leathers, seam-scar raw,
sang prickle hymns in cobbler-stench.

that nettle-beast with guggle spine;
It chews the holes from inside out
and gulps the brads like clove and brine.”

that stitchspike keen with quiver haft;
Its bradbright gleam along the wall
threw prinkish stars about the craft.

Through clötter-night and shingle-drift
he paced the lanes of hide and glue;
The skiver breeze went needle-swift,
and snurly moths in flutters flew.

Out from the strop-tree, whisper-wet,
the Thrumblegrin uncoiled its jaw;
A rimple-tail like thuttering net,
and clackclaws tapping rawk-rawk raw.

It blinked with button-borrel eyes—
two greeby lamps of nubbly lume—
And Finlo, bold in cobbler guise,
went prickety-prack to meet his doom.

He feinted left, he jinked to right,
then thrust the awl in stitcher’s arc;
A twizzle-turn, a braddle-bite,
and poke! the point found thrumble-mark.

The Thrumblegrin gave scrattle-yow,
leather-scented thunder broke;
It fratched and folded, dwindling now,
to naught but holes and drift of smoke.

Back to the bench he trundled home,
his awl-tip warm with workwell pride;
Old cobbles hummed in gristy loam,
and brimble-lanterns bobbed beside.

At frammil dusk the scrimble shaws
still whorl-and-whittle by the bench;
The awl keeps hush with bradbright jaws,
while mending songs un-scrieve the scrench.

poem:
The Snickle-Creep

In grumbleglow the hedges leaned,
Besloshed with mist and thistle-sheen;
The snickle-creep, all shadow-creened,
Went snargling through the guddle-green.

“Mind, spryling, mind the Creep,” they said,
“It shimmles under cellar-stone;
It pats the ankle, winks the dread—
Go armed, go wise, and not alone.”

And slung my bramble-buckle pack;

Where nettles hiss and pebbles peep;
The wind went winkles in the grain,
And somewhere near, I heard it creep.

It sidled soft as falling soot;
Its whisper had a thistled grin,
Its fingers were a fidget-foot.

The Wantward Way

the signs all stern and true.

the tanglefence is slow;
take yearnstrait through the hushy late,
where grassblood learns to glow.”

a tramplewhisp was born;
the croonhedge leaned, the slick-sedge schooled,
and shinpath showed at morn.

new wantlets names by name;
the ground remembers every switch

poem:
Mizzlewisp Morning

It was the mizzletide; the lanes
were murkled, meek, and low;
the hedgerows wore their pearlèd grains,
and cockerels crowed too slow.

"Beware the foglings, sproutling mine,"
said Gran with furrowed brow;
"they snorfle-drift and snuggle-spine—
so keep your tucker now.

Bring blinker-lamp and snicket-staff,
and zip your zodden coat;
the mizzle mumbles, odd as chaff,
and nibbles at your throat."

I wound my snither-scarf about
my chatter-chin and nose;
I packed a bun and ventured out
where mizzlewisping goes.

The fog came fuzzle-puzzlewise,
a fluther, thick and pale;
it sworled along in glozzled sighs
and blurred the gate and rail.

From gutter-gloom a Fog-a-loo
went thrumple, soft and soft;
it lapped the fence and hedgerow too
and muffled up the loft.

I whirled my snicket-staff askew,
and dingled bell and sang;
"Begone, you drifty, drabbly stew!"
my braveheart drumlet rang.

It dwindled into snorfs and threads,
it thimled up the lane,
till dawnlet tipped the chimney-heads
and gilt the window-pane.

Back home I skipped with dew-bright boots,
and crusty loaf in sack;
"O hallaloo!" cried mugs and flutes—
"our mizzle's turned its back!"

Now ends the mizzlewisp; the lanes
unmurkle, bright and new;
the hedgerows shake their pearlèd grains—
sing hallaloo, halloo!

Third-Rail Thrumble

do glisk and gloom through iron scum,
the sleepers crouch, the ballast cramps,
and all is thrung with third rail hum.

Mind-gap and sheath your fingerlings,
for sparkers make a snicker-plum;
with copper whisk and whisper-wings
stalks Voltivor, the Raildrum.

I took my stave of wooden proof,
my amber lamp with saffron bloom;
I tiptoed by the dripper-roof
to where it purred—third rail hum.

It trembled low, it thrimmed it high,
a fizzlewhirr, a brackletune;
then Voltivor unshuttered eye
and zampled forth in zingazoon.

Its jaws were forks of nickel gnash,
its whiskers hissed with ohmy-glow;
I held my distance—no brash dash—
and let the humward currents flow.

It cooed a carglow lullaby,
then swirled back down the tunnel-plum;
and all the rails went shiver-sly,
still singing, singing: third rail hum.

The Sprocketwock

In dimble hour the silver rolls
Did whirr and whumble-tune,
The sprocketlings through velvet backs
Went clitter-clatter soon;
All mimbly-gray the bokeh bloomed,
A lens—moon-mouthed—would grin,
The redlamp gloamed in darkroom womb
And beckoned us within.

“Keep safe,” quoth elder Photo-pap,
“The Sprocketwock beware!
Its jangle-fangs can shred a frame
To tassel-ribbon air.
Shun Leak-o-Light, that tricksy bird,
And Dustygrubs that scratch;
And never sneeze in loading-time—
It spoils a tender batch.”

He grasped the clickersnapper-box,
All leatherette and brass,
He primed the winder—shnick-a-whirr!—
To let the first frame pass;
He set the stop to f/8 clean,
The time to one-two-five,
ASA four-oh-oh he chose
To let the shadows thrive.

Through alleys neon-slick he crept
To stalk the flicker-thing,
Past cinema ghosts and lamplit posts
Where silverlings take wing;
He paused beside a tripod tree
And in his viewdream peered,
While chemistry of nerves and night
Made all the hush grow weird.

Soft from the billboard bramble-vale
The Snapperwock drew near;
Its shutter-lids went click-a-bit—
A tick he well could hear;
Its motorwind went whiffling-burr
With burble-whirly bound,
And beetle-beaked a lenshood bobbed
In circles, round and round.

Click-snick! the curtains stitched the light;
The aperture went blink;
He held his breath a whisker’s width
Upon the focus brink;
He wound again—ka-chunk, ka-chunk—
Prepared another pass,
And trapped a phantom city-bird
In silver-salted glass.

He sealed the reel in darkness black
With fingertip and feel,
He danced the chemicoil gavotte:
The soup, the stop, the seal;
Dev bath to sway, then lemon-stop,
And fixer, stout and stout,
He rinsed and swished the silver skin
Till ghosty shapes came out.

He hung the negatives to drip,
Each frame a glimmer-raft,
Grainlings hummed in pebble-drift,
A crackle-moony craft;
He proofed a tidy contact sheet—
Small midnight-ticking clocks—
And laughed to see the captured beast
Within its sprocket-box.

“Have you unjammed the Sprocketwock?”
Cried Photo-pap, astir.
“Didst tame its grunchy grinding teeth
And bid its jangle purr?”
“O snapful day!” the youngster sang,
“Clackoo! Clackay! Huzza!”
He waved the glossy glazzle-sheets—
“Behold! Hurray! Hurray!”

In dimble hour the silver rolls
Still whirr and whumble-tune,
The sprocketlings through velvet backs
Go clitter-clatter soon;
All mimbly-bright the bokeh blooms,
The lens wears moonish grin—
And pictures purr in shoebox dens:
Come, spool the dream again.

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Galvorn's Thrall"

'Twas brillig on the metro line,
Where voltaged rails did eerily shine,
A hum of dread, a zing of might,
As Galvorn, beast of sparks, took flight.

With frazzle wings, a-whir in air,
It sipped the current, void of care,
Its gromble maw, agape with glee,
Drank in the power, wild and free.

The strid of trains, a-rumble went,
As Galvorn's hum, a-thrall was bent,
The passengers, with wits a-blur,
Felt mystic dread, and creeping fur.

Beware, O traveler, this spark-born thing,
Lest Galvorn's thrall, thy senses cling,
And thou, in wonder, lost and grey,
Become a captive of its voltaic sway.

The frumious hum, a-sizzle spun,
As Galvorn feasted, till the day was done,
And when the night, its shadows brought,
The creature slumbered, sparks uncaught.
label: low

prompt: Write a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"Burnin's Bane of Glowing Screens"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In screenlit rooms, with visions dire
Their LCDs aglow, with images stuck
A ghastly fate, by Burnin's pluck

Beware, ye users of displays bright
Lest icons linger, and ghosts take flight
Frayn your screens, with changing views
Lest permanent marks, your sight subdue

In Slithy's realm, of pixels worn
A gruesome fate, for those who scorn
To adjust their settings, with gentle care
And thus, their screens, with ghosts impair

He took a Pixelstick, in hand so fine
And tweaked the settings, in wondrous shrine
Image retention, by his art did cease
And Burnin's bane, no longer release

Then back he went, to rooms of delight
Where screens shone bright, without a blight
His friends all cheered, and raised their tea
"Huzzah! The screens, are ghost-free!"

With Vorpal settings, and careful might
He conquered Burnin, and banished fright
And if thou heed, this tale of old
Thy screens shall shine, with stories untold.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Throcklepox Echoes"

'Twas brillig and slothsom in tunnel's keep,
Where momey whispers spawned and secrets creep.
A frazzlewump's faint voice did resound,
In Throcklepox's hollow, eerie profound.

Beware the Glibblejaws, with ears so fine,
That stalk and listen with wily design.
Their flumplenooks a-twitch, as whispers play,
They echo-hunt, by dawn's dismaying ray.

Throcklepox echoes, a wondrous fright,
Refract the sounds, in endless, mournful night.
Glibblejaws convene, with cunning guile,
To snare the whispers, in their echo pile.

Frazzlewump's whisper-wraiths, now lost, now found,
In Throcklepox's heart, a labyrinth wound.
Tread softly, traveler, lest echoing fate,
Betray thy secrets, to the Glibblejaws' wait.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about printer jam in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"The Frumious Fiasco of the Printer's Woe"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In rec rooms of the office high
All flumplenooks of paper lief
Did chatter, whisper, and jargon rife

Beware the jam, my son, I pray
That scars the sheet and darkens day
With fangs of twisted, crumpled spite
It doth devour the printed light

I galloped forth with gallant zeal
To conquer this most woeful reveal
I seized the offending sheet with care
And, frumious, I did rend the air

With snicker-snack and wanton will
I pleaded with the printer still
To free the jam and let it be
That workflow might proceed with glee

And lo! The frumious fiasco's might
Did yield to patience and my plight
The paper free, the printer sang
A yesifer of renewed delight that rang

And I returned, with valor unmarred
Having conquered the jam's dark regard
So heed this tale of woe and tribulation
And always keep a care in preparation!
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Gallimaufry of Forgotten Moments"

'Twas brillig and the slithy Vathlox flew
Through frumious loops of memory anew
Beware the Déjàront, my son, with care
Lest thou fall prey to its recurvous snare

'Twas a feeling most curious and bright
A glimmer of remembrance, a wistful sight
As if the Chronowl, with wily guile
Had stolen moments from thy former while

The Borog الاح of familiarity bred
A shiver down thy spine, a twitching dread
That thou hadst lived this moment erstbefore
In some bygone era, lost in thought's great score

In this gallimaufry of forgotten moments dear
Thou searchest for the thread of reason, but 'tis unclear
Whether 'tis but a trick of the mind's eye
Or some glimpse of a life that's yet to come, anon, to try.

prompt: Write a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"Melodoria's Menace and Merry Return"

In twilight's hush, where shadows play,
In Melodoria's music room we stray,
Beware the Screechpipes, loud and long,
That shrill thy ears and make thy song go wrong.

Beware the Fiddlewraith's wailing sigh,
And Gobblingroups that gobble, passing by,
Their Cacophontrain will leave thee dizzy and pale,
Unless thou wearest thy Discordsail.

He took the Chordkat in hand, so fine,
With silken strings and tuneful twine,
He ventured forth to face the din,
And conquer discord with a savory grin.

He conquered first the Pianodrone's hum,
Then wrestled with the Growlinground's low thrum,
He leapt o'er Cymbalclashes, avoiding Fizz,
And landed light, where harmonies did buzz.

He found the sweet Harmonlings, dancing bright,
Their Songsirens beckoning, shining fair and light,
He joined their chorus, twirling in delight,
With symphonies that lifted him in flight.

Now, returned from Melodoria's Menace dire,
He celebrates with melodies on fire,
The TuneKnights gather 'round, their cheers to share,
For he, brave adventurer, showed courage rare.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
Glibblebay's Lamentable Lay

'Twas brillig on the Layover bay
Where frazzlewings in whimsy play
And mome-like, travelers did stray
With luggage lost in disarray

Beware the Snurfle, my son!
With claws of customs and eyes of fun
It pounces on the unwary guest
And confiscates their luggage best

The frumious flights, they come and go
Leaving weary souls to wail and know
The pangs of hunger, the sting of night
In Glibblebay, where delays take flight

He took the vorpal voucher in hand
And sought the mystical land
Of Reimbursalia, where claims are made
And the losses of the layover trade

But alas, the Snurfle lay in wait
And with a snicker, sealed his fate
The traveler's plea, it fell on deaf ears
In Glibblebay, where woe and wail appear

So if thou ever find'st thyself astray
In this, the most woeful of bays
Beware the Snurfle's wily guile
And may thy layover be but a short while!

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"The Creep of Wugglepants"

Beware the Creep, my child, I say,
With skin as pale as moon in May,
Eyes that gleam like embers bright,
And fingers long, like wraiths in night.

His wugglepants, a curious sight,
Flail like tentacles, soft and light,
As he glides forth, with stealthy ease,
Through shadows dark, where victims freeze.

Beware his snickering, snaffling sound,
As he snuffles out his woe-begone ground,
The frumplenooks, that dance with glee,
As he conjures up his wicked spree.

But thou, brave adventurer, beware,
Take heed of Creep's most cunning snare,
His jim-jam wiles, that weave a spell,
And lure thee in, to his wuggle hell.

Yet fear not, noble heart, for thou art bold,
Thy valorous spirit, shall never grow old,
So arm thyself, with valor's might,
And face the Creep, in morning light.

Then, when thou return'st, with triumph's cry,
The frumplenooks, shall dance, and flutter by,
And Wugglepants, shall be laid low,
As thou, brave hero, dost thy story grow.

So here's to thee, brave adventurer true,
May thy return, be joyful, and anew,
With Creep, o'erthrown, and wugglepants tamed,
And frumplenooks, in jubilant praise, inflamed!

"Glibblejaws' Shortcut"

Yet Glibblejaws, undeterred, did swiftly pass

"Beware, O traveler, of the shortcut's thread"
But still he pressed, with purpose in his stride
Through glimmering gloam, where shadows softly reside

He traversed Flishybog, a quag of uncertain fate
And dodged the Jinkleplack, with eyes that glowed too late
The Glibblejaws, with valor unassailed, did stride

"Mornfogle's Mystic Veil"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In Mornfogle's misty, mystic fire
The fog arose with wraithy sway
And wrapped the world in vaprous gray

Beware, traveler, of Fimbulfly's snare
That lurks within the cloudy lair
With Flishyblop's deceitful song
It'll lead thee astray, all day long

But fear not, for the Fizzlethorn's might
Shall guide thee through the darkening light
Thy Galumphocks, with sturdy tread
Shall traverse the misty path ahead

As Glimmerbats begin to play
And Flumplenooks dance, in joyous array
The sun shall burst, with radiant beam
And chase the fog's befuddling dream

Then, with a cry of "Frogglegay!"
Thou shalt emerge, into the new day
With heart afire, and spirit free
Thy path unwinding, in clarity

"Galvanic Thrum of the Third Rail's Might"

Among the tracks, where electric dreams were made
Their snouts a-twitch, as they sensed with glee
The galvanic thrum, a humming spree

Its zorching force, a frumious snare
That fries the flesh and crisps the air
Leaving naught but a smoldering lair

The Borogoves of the subway deep
Did dance and caper, with steps asleep
Their ears a-tingle, as the hum did rise
A gaseous vortex, that opened wide their eyes

He took the Rail of Power, with hands so fine
And felt the Throcklepox, a buzzing spine
The Gromwoks watched, as he rode the line
With sparks a-flying, like a wizard's sign

And when he reached the platform's end
The Third Rail's song, did his senses attend
A symphony, of voltage and might
That left him shaken, in the pale moon's light.

poem:
"Snapwhirle's Gambit"

'Twas brillig and sloths did gyre
In the land of F-Stop's sweet fire
All mimsy were the shutters' sway
As I prepared for a photographic day

Beware the Snapwhirle, my son!
The lens that doth devour the sun
Beware the Flibber's wily grasp
Lest thy exposures be aghast

I took my trusty camera in hand
And loaded film of finest brand
The Snizzle frazzled, the Whirloos spun
As I set forth to capture the day's begun

I chased the Luminari's fleeting gleam
Through alleys, streets, and verdant dream
I snapped and clicked with merry cheer
As images danced upon the ether clear

At last I returned, my quest complete
The Snapwhirle's secrets at my feet
I developed my film with glee
And beheld the wonders that I'd see

Oh, frabjous day! Oh, joyful sight!
The photos danced with color and delight
The Flibber's grasp had not prevailed
My Snapwhirle's Gambit had set sail

Huzzah! I cried, my journey's end
The land of F-Stop, my heart doth commend.

poem:
**The Glimmergrin’s Snicker-Snack**  

Beware the Glimmergrin, my son!  
The mirrormaw’s quibber-quib!  
His snicker-snick with frumious fun  
Doth twist the gloombark’s lullaby.  

Through underpass’s shadowed throat,  
The echo’s wail doth splinter air—  
A zibber-zib, a sproing, a note  
That gnaws the dusk and swallows prayer.  

He guards the key to silent spheres,  
Where time doth flicker, dim and thin,  
With jaws of rust and eyes of gears,  
And tongue of static, shrill and thin.  

I swung my gloombark, sharp and low,  
Yet still the echo’s laugh did thrive—  
A thousand selves in fractured show,  
Each one a thief of my own life.  

Now lo! The Glimmergrin doth flee,  
His snicker-snick dissolved in breeze…  
But lingering, the underpass still sings  
Of all that’s lost in echoes’ tease.

**Dahjublarky**  

Beware the Dahjublark, my son!  
The glee-glimmerings are in the glen,  
And shun the Zizzlewink's droll tron,  
And shun the Twizzlethrum's sly den.  

He took his Frizzlefluff and went,  
Through Mizzlefritz and Doodleflame,  
Where the Glimmerling birds in wockets sent  
A clatter of echoes through the frame.  

The Twizzlethrum, with squinty eyes,  
Did whisper *“Vorple, vorple, vorple!”*  
Its mane of mist and clockwork sighs  
Did twist the hours into a snarl.  

He met the Twizzlethrum, and he did snicker-snork,  
And hobbled home with a wibbly wisp,  
Yet in his breast the old thrill sparkled—  
A ghostly glee, a prior kiss.  

The Dahjublark, with a glee-glimmer,  
Sang tales of now and never.  
His heart, a riddle, still remember-  
The world’s a loop, the end’s a begin.

Beware the Clatterthorn’s croon, its twinkle is a snare,  
The Quibble-Quo’s soft whisper, *“Tis the way to despair!”*  

He met the Fizzlefry’s flutter, a flicker of gold,

He bumblewurz’d through the *mizzle-mock* to the *glimmergrin’s* crack.

He braved the *pibble-pop* and the *razzle-razz*,

With the *snicker-snack* in hand, he returns to the light,

The *quibble-quo* quoth, *“No more shall you swerve!”*

**The Mimsy Minstrel**  

In the mimsy minstrel's den, where the echoes gnash and gleam,  
I spied a fiddle-dee-faddle, and a trombone's glum squint.  
The walls were lined with wibble-wobble, and the floor with *snicker-snack*,  
Where *quibber-quibber* strings did thrum, and *flibbertigibbet* keys did *clink*.  

"Mind the *borples*!" cried the *bloop*, "their *zizzlebugs* dance with grins,  
They’ll steal your rhythm and your *grobble-groble* if you *wibble* too much!"  
So I gripped my *glimmering glockenspiel* and stepped through the *flim-flam* door,  
Where the *snicker-snack* of a *fizzle-frazzle* did *floop* and *flirt* and *flourish* more.  

I met a *quizzle-queue* with a *twizzle-twine* in its paw,  
It hummed a *burbled-burble* and *banged* a *wibble-wobble* drum.  
The *snicker-snack* of a *flim-flam* did *floop* and *flirt* and *flourish* more,  
Till I *burbled-burble*ed it, and it *quibber-quibber*ed *“* *gloom* *!”*  

Then came the *glorium*—a *zizzlebug* crown,  
With *flibbertigibbet* notes that *snickered* and *snared*.  
I swung my *glimmering glockenspiel*, and the *snicker-snack* did *frown*,  
And the *zizzlebugs* all *wibble-wobbled* to the *bloop* of the *flim-flam* sound.  

And back I came with a *wibble-wobble*, and a *glurgle-glug* of cheer,  
The *borples* now *quibber-quibber*ed, and the *flim-flam* sang *“* *fiddle-dee* *!”*  
So heed the *mimsy minstrel*—its *snicker-snack* is near,  
But *burbled-burble* and *flibbertigibbet* will *floop* you back to *gloom* and *flourish*!

**The Monte Carlo Mimsy**  

Beware the gorp of Monte Carlo,  
Where flim-flam wibbles through the air,  
The croupier’s grin (a snicker-snack!)  
Will steal your coins and leave you bare.  

Take heed, ye punters, bold and bright,  
The roulette’s whisper, *“Wibble-wobble!”*  
For every spin, a gloop of fright,  
And cards that moan in gurgling tides.  

The Riviera’s haze, a mimsy haze,  
Where dice are drolls and clocks defy,  
The casino’s heart (a thrumming glee)  
Beats *“Beware the blorp!”* as you draw nigh.  

You’ll meet the *glop* with eyes aglow,  
Its paws like coins, its tail a thread,  
It’ll say, “*To gamble is to go!*”  
Then snap your chips with a *snicker-snack*!  

But flee the *flim-flam’s* sly lilt, ye brave,  
For every win is but a dream—  
The *wibble-wobble* hums your name,  
Then steals your soul (or just your steam).  

Yet when you rise, though battered, bright,  
With pockets light and laughter bold,  
The Monte Carlo moon will light  
Your path, and toast your gambler’s gold!  

Hooray for Monte Carlo!  
Where folly dances, wild and free—  
A realm of *glop* and *snicker-snack*,  
And *flim-flam*’s song for you and me!

Beware the throb of the thrum-Thunk, the zizzle-zoo that gnarls,

**The Glimmerwig's Lament**  

In the realm of the flimflam, where the virelum grows,  
A path of the pining winds through the thistle and rose.  
The sproing of the sly, with a whispering cheer,  
Guided the seeker to where the Glimmerwig's near.  

With eyes of the glimmer and a tail of the twine,  
It hums a soft snicker-snack, a most jingling sign.  
"O wayfarer, quester, what do you seek in this glen?  
A token of longing, or a whisper again?"  

The seeker replied with a quibber's refrain,  
"Through the mire of the maybe, I chase the vague chain!"  
The Glimmerwig tilted its fractal head,  
And spat a bright fizzle, then cackled, "Be fed!"  

It fed them the frizzle, the zing, and the thrum,  
Till the heart's buried echo ran wild in the lump.  
But the path, once desired, is a riddle unbound—  
A sly, spiraling maze where the yearning is found.  

Now the Glimmerwig dwells where the wantons may tread,  
A cryptic, clattering ghost, both the wound and the thread.  
And the path, though it wavers, through the voids never dies—  
For the soul is a virelum, and the quest is its eyes.
label: medium

**The Scienzor's Quest**  

Beware the Flibber-jibber, with its snicker-snack!  
Where the grommels growl and the bumblebees hack!  
The quibber-queen’s in the lab, with a wizzle-wobble glare,  
She’ll snort your hypotheses into a tangle of snare!  

Gather your glorp, your zing-zen, your twizzle-popper spy,  
And batten your mind against the *flim-flam flail* and *sproingy* lie!  
For the quantum-queen’s riddle’s a *bloop-bloop* in the night,  
And the *crinkle-crank* may spin you into a *quibber-rit*!  

With a *snicker-snack* of courage, you’ll dash through the halls,  
Past the *fizzle-floop* and the *bloop-bloop* of all!  
The *glorp-gears* whirr, the *wizzle-wire* sings,  
As you battle the *quibber-queen* with a *sproingy* grin!  

Then lo! You return with a *flim-flam flair*,  
Your *bloop-bloop* perfected, your *sproingy* laid bare!  
The crowd shouts *“Glee-gee!”* with a *zig-zag cry*,  
And the *crinkle-crank* bows to the *wizzle-wire’s* high!

poem:
**The Fogling's Lament**  

Beneath the pallid, prismatic sky,  
The Glimmerfluff doth crawl and sigh,  
With whispering wickets, wibbling wide,  
And hushed, half-hums that never die.  

The Snicker-Snack of the Slithy Borne  
Doth flicker, fumble, fritter, torn,  
While the Wibblewags, with waggish air,  
Sip the mist from thimble-shaped thorns.  

Beware the Blear-Beast, with eyes of cream,  
That gobbles gloom and swallows time,  
Its jibber-jabber, jibber-jabber,  
And turns the daylight into rhyme!  

The Mizzle-Monger, with muzzy mind,  
Doth stitch the sun with silver thread,  
Till all the world is softly spun  
In silken, silver, sleepy thread.

poem:
**The Conferencetroll's Lament**  

Beware the Slacktide's glib tongue,  
And the Zoombeast's glaring eye,  
For the Meeple in their gowns  
Doth nibble the wits of the wise.  

With a Cafetron in hand and a Whirlygig's cheer,  
The Bold One strode through the Loomroom's mire,  
Where the Bolverine hums and the Droneticks creep,  
And the PPTs flicker with ghostly fire.  

"O frabjous day!" he cried, "Beware the Lurk!  
Its clatter is sharp, its chatter is wide,  
It slays with a scroll of a thousand words,  
And the Wobbler's wail in the corridor's side!"  

He whiffled the Droneticks with a Snicker-snack,  
And the Lurk did gyre and gimble with fright,  
Then he fled through the doors of the Somnambler's trap,  
And the meeting's last snore did fade into night.  

Oh, hooray! The Bold One returns with a grin,  
His briefcase now light, his brain quite unscathed,  
For the Conferencetroll is no more a din—  
He’s slain it with laughter and sipped the Cognacore!

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
**The Thrum of the Tresrail**  

In the Gloam where the Zizzle thrums,  
Beneath the steel that never hums,  
The Quibber flits with a flicker bright,  
Through the shadowed tracks of the midnight light.  

Beware the Quibber, with its snicker-snick,  
Whose fangs are wires and whose eyes are slick!  
It binks the bolter and the sprocket's plight,  
And slithy toves in the twilight bite.  

He took his quibber-sword in hand,  
Long did he trudge through the strobber land,  
With a fumph and a flim, he chased the train,  
Till the clatter of wheels did not remain.  

And all in a snicker-snick he saw,  
The Quibber, with its whirring jaw,  
And the clatter of gears in a clatter-way,  
And he went to the brink of the third-rail sway.  

With a fizzle and a flick, he gave the blow,  
The Quibber's wires snapped in a sputter-show,  
And the tracks did echo with a sizzle-sing,  
As the creature fell into the static spring.  

Now rest the Quibber, its hum is still,  
And the rails are safe, and the night is chill.  
The tramp of the train in the strobber's gleam,  
Bears the tale of the third-rail dream.
label: high

**The Snicker-Snack of the Glowing Snail**  

Beware the Glowing Snail, with its flicker-flame eyes,  
Who gnaws the screen with a gloop-gnash, and leaves phantom trails!  
The Muck-Whiff of the Pixel, its whispering *quizzle-chorus*,  
Will etch your glow in a *wibble-wobble* that never will cease.  

With *zibber-zabber* claws, it scampers through the code,  
A *flimflam* of static, a *gloop* in the glow.  
The *snarl-snoot* of the light, where the shadows conspire,  
Leaves *dazzle-dregs* on your face, like a ghostly *bling-bloom*.  

Oh, flit the *sproing-sprock*! Oh, dash the *bong-bang*!  
The *quizzle-quest* is dire—prepare your *crinkle-crank*!  
For every *blink-bleep* you linger, the *fizzle-floss* grows,  
And your screen wears a *wibble-wobble* that no *sproing-sprock* can wash.  

But when you flee the *muck-whiff*, and swipe the *glorp-gloop*,  
The *snicker-snack* shall sigh, and the *flimflam* shall stop.  
Your display, once *dazzle-dregs*, now *zing-zang* with cheer—  
A *bliss-bloom*! A *bingle-bang*! The *glorp-glop* is near!

poem:
**The Dèjá Vu of the Glimmergrin**  

Burbled the zizzlewinks in the quibble-doodle dusk,  
Where the Glimmergrin slithers, a frumious wisp.  
I saw the same moon, the same mist, the same twinkle—  
A mogwump of echoes, a snicker-snack twinkle.  

The Glimmergrin grinned, "You’ve crossed the same path before!  
A bumblesnoot dream, a quibber’s encore.  
The wibber-woe hums, the sproing of the day—  
But the clockwork of yesterdays sings in your fray!"  

I fled through the grumblegrain, the snorfle-veil,  
Past the pibble-puddle where the shiver-sprites sail.  
The Glimmergrin called, "You’re trapped in a riddle!  
A wibble-wobble, a sproing of the middle!"  

Now I wake, still tingling with the Glimmergrin’s thrum—  
A dèjá vu’s whisper, a sproing of the sum.  
The world’s a soft mumble, a quibble-doodle rhyme,  
And the Glimmergrin’s laughing in every "I’ve seen this before."

**The Lament of the Layover Bay**  

Beware the Snickerclaw, with its glorbish grin,  
In Layover Bay, where the Zibby trees begin.  
The flimflam winds whisper, "Beware the fray,  
For the Borogrove's moan is a slithy decay!"  

The Burbler bore a quibber, sharp and grim,  
To slay the Glimmerflit, that riddle-voiced swim.  
It rustled through the mire, a frumious trail,  
With eyes of prismatic shale and a snicker-snack wail.  

"O frabjous day!" the Burbler cried,  
As the Glimmerflit danced, a phantom in the tide.  
It spun with zibby-zeal, a tangle of spun glass,  
And left the Burbler baffled, in a clatter of phlegm and pass.  

Yet lo! The Snickerclaw, with its glorbish grin,  
Did leap from the mist, a gloop of green and thin.  
But the Burbler, with quibber and grit,  
Slew it with a *snicker-snack*, and the Bay was a bit.  

Now Layover Bay sleeps, a lullaby of tide,  
Where the Glimmerflit hums, and the Zibby trees glide.  
Beware the Snickerclaw, with its glorbish grin—  
Its tale is a slithy song, now etched in the skin.

The Creep of Clinking Climes  
Beware the Creep of Clinking Climes,  
Where shadows twist and wibble-wobble times!  
The snicker-snack shall snicker-snoot,  
And flim-flam the fizzle-floop's foot.  

With fizzle-floop and wibble-wobble,  
I sought the Creep through dusk and dabble.  
The sizzle-sproing of silent trees,  
Did dazzle-dook with ghostly glees.  

Its eyes were glimmerwink, its breath was zizzle-zoom,  
A labyrinth of whispers, a jumble of gloom.  
It chased me with a snicker-snack,  
I fled with a flim-flam, my heart a fluttering clock.  

I seized the snicker-snack, I swung the snicker-snoot,  
And sliced the Creep with a wibble-wobble boot!  
The flim-flam wailed, the fizzle-floop fell,  
And the glimmerwink dimmed, as if in farewell.  

Now home I come, with triumph's cheer,  
The snicker-snack my trophy, my hard-won prize here.  
Beware the Creep, o'er creaking floors,  
But fear not, for with flim-flam we'll conquer its claws!

**The Zibberwink's Lament**  

In the glimmerflit’s realm where the quibbers creep,  
Where the slythmire winds in a spiral of sleep,  
The Zibberwink’s path, a crooked design,  
A trail of the heart, not the laws of the line.  

Burbled the dusk with a sproing of glee,  
As the wibberwack prowled through the sproingtree.  
“O frabjous day!” the querulous cried,  
“Beware the snicker-snack of the sproingtree’s pride!”  

With a flim-flam and fizzle, the seeker did tread,  
Past the grizzlegrin moss and the thimblethrum seed.  
The Zibberwink coiled in a glissando swirl,  
Its eyes like a zibbity blaze, its tail a dry whirl.  

“Take heed, o querulous!” the creature did cry,  
“Thy desire-path is a sproingy sigh!  
Each step is a sproing, each breath a sproing,  
Till the heart’s own sproing echoes through the sproing!”  

And the seeker did leap through the sproingy night,  
A quibber of dreams in a sproingy fight.  
The Zibberwink screeched, “O sproing! O sproing!  
Thy sproingy quest is but sproing, sproing!”  

Yet the seeker did grin, “I shall sproing, I shall sproing!”  
And the path, once a sproing, became a sproing.  
For the sproingy heart, though sproingy and sproing,  
Is the sproingiest sproing that the sproing can sproing.

poem:
**Whiffle-Whiffle Dawn**  

The glorp of the morn did gyre and gimble,  
In slithy toves with a flim-flam flame,  
The snicker-snack of the mist did clamber,  
And burbled blibber through the drowsy frame.  

Beware the quibber-quib, with flim-flam mane,  
Its wibbles wobble and its snicks snick, the sly—  
The frabjous fog may twist your brain,  
And leave you lost in a blicker-bly.  

With runcible eyes and a snicker-snack blade,  
It lurks in the grove where the gloom doth creep,  
But take a thrumple, don’t be afraid,  
And chase the glook-glook with a glisten-slip.  

The wibbles wobble, the snicks snick, the sly,  
Through mimsy paths where the murtle doth play;  
The fogling’s tale is a burble-bly,  
Till the frabjous day, the fog doth flee.  

Then glorp and gimble, the sun doth gleam,  
And the whiffle-whiffle sings, "The tale is done!"  
With a snicker-snack slash and a blicker-bly cheer,  
We triumph, we twinkle, we bumble and run!

**The Cluck-Whirr's Quest**  

Beware the Cluck-Whirr, my son!  
The lens-loon that devours the sun!  
Beware the snicker-snack, the whirr-whorl,  
And shun the shutter-sproing's scrawl!  

With flicker-flame and glimmer-glop,  
He lurks where the light-lobes crop.  
His gears hum *tink-tink-tink*, his eye  
A pixel-pule that swallows sky!  

But take thy roll of ghostly film,  
And chase the shadow-palace grim!  
For though he snarls, and thrums, and twirls,  
Thy click-clack shall unspool his curls!  

Then hark! The shutter-sproing's cry—  
A twinkle-troop of stars will fly!  
The Cluck-Whirr’s wail, a mirthful groan,  
As film-fairies dance at last, alone!  

Now sing, oh cine-chorus, loud!  
The celluloid’s triumphant crowd!  
For every frame, a fleeting cheer—  
The world’s a *cheer-chime* we hold dear!
